The sword in this passage is metaphorical, even Micah 6:7 which He quoted isn't talking about a battle but a righteous man living in a fallen world. Matthew 26:52 is addressing specific physical violence, because Peter really did cut off someone's ear with a sword, and Jesus healed the wound.

Paul says don't be a fool, talk it over and resolve it before it does kill you.

Elijah was taken (not under his own power) into heaven by God which is clear in 2 Kings 2:1,3,5, and 10. Similarly Enoch was taken by God (Genesis 5:24). If we call upon God's mercies and turn from evil to walk in His Ways, He will turn away the destruction we deserve. God "repented" because Moses called upon His mercy, and pointed out that the destruction of the nation was contrary to His Word to the fathers of the nation. The Bible admits there's a contradiction! Moses stepped in and called God's hand, even though Moses probly wanted rid of the nation, he never wanted the job, later he was forbidden to enter the Promised Land because he was so angry with them he disobeyed God's command in the sight of the nation. So Moses, denying himself, instead had compassion for a people he didn't like (and in many cases the feeling was mutual), became a model for the Messiah that would come and die for sins He didn't commit on behalf of a world that shunned Him. God now had record of what He planned to do in the future regarding the Messiah. As for that moment, the nation itself was spared, those that incited the rebellion were not spared, showing while God did turn from obliterating the whole nation save for Moses, He did not turn from visiting His anger on the instigators. This may seem foreign if you think the Bible is a fable, but the concept is found throughout the Bible from Abraham throughout the New Testament. I can't see how an example of intercessory prayer turning away God's wrath is a discrepency if you're using the Bible itself as the measure of it being false.
